docs.abstract: It remains unclear if the effort to enlist companies like General Motors, Apple and Hanes constitutes an effective strategy.
docs.snippet: It remains unclear if the effort to enlist companies like General Motors, Apple and Hanes constitutes an effective strategy.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s refusal to invoke the Defense Production Act to commandeer resources for the federal government is based on a bet that he can cajole the nation’s biggest manufacturers and tech firms to come together in a market-driven, if chaotic, consortium that will deliver critical equipment — from masks to ventilators — in time to abate a national crisis.

headline.main: Trump Bets Business Will Answer Call to Fight Virus, but Strategy Bewilders Firms
headline.print_headline: Trump Counts on Private Sector for Supplies

byline.original: By David E. Sanger, Ana Swanson and Maggie Haberman

docs.abstract: Both tech giants’ app stores carry Absher, which lets male “guardians” track women’s movements — or even stop them from getting on a plane.
docs.snippet: Both tech giants’ app stores carry Absher, which lets male “guardians” track women’s movements — or even stop them from getting on a plane.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A Saudi mobile application that lets men track and restrict the movements of women in the kingdom has come under increased scrutiny this week with an American senator and rights groups urging Apple and Google to remove it from their platforms, accusing the technology giants of facilitating gender discrimination.

headline.main: Apple and Google Urged to Dump Saudi App That Lets Men Track Women
headline.print_headline: Apple and Google Urged to Dump Saudi App That Lets Men Track Women

docs.abstract: As Uber and Lyft go public, financial interest in getting truly driverless cars on the road will mount. That shouldn’t mean it happens in a rush.
docs.snippet: As Uber and Lyft go public, financial interest in getting truly driverless cars on the road will mount. That shouldn’t mean it happens in a rush.
docs.lead_paragraph: Greetings from London. Here’s a look at the week’s tech news:

headline.main: The Week in Tech: Who Should Let Driverless Cars Off the Leash?
headline.print_headline: In Demand, but Far From Ready

docs.abstract: The iPhone maker is partnering with Hollywood heavyweights and publishers to provide broad new services to its users.
docs.snippet: The iPhone maker is partnering with Hollywood heavyweights and publishers to provide broad new services to its users.
docs.lead_paragraph: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Apple unveiled a new video streaming service on Monday with a parade of celebrities rarely seen on a stage outside of Hollywood’s awards season, with heavyweight directors like Steven Spielberg and J. J. Abrams and stars like Octavia Spencer and Jennifer Aniston.

headline.main: Apple Unveils Video Service With Celebrity Parade but Few Details
headline.print_headline: With Sales Flattening, Apple Pivots Into Content

byline.original: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and John Koblin

docs.abstract: The rules that Apple, Google, Facebook and Twitter follow in their roles as arbiters of online speech are often vague. Critics say they are arbitrary.
docs.snippet: The rules that Apple, Google, Facebook and Twitter follow in their roles as arbiters of online speech are often vague. Critics say they are arbitrary.
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple, Google and Facebook this week erased from their services many — but not all — videos, podcasts and posts from the right-wing conspiracy theorist Alex Jones and his Infowars site. And Twitter left Mr. Jones’s posts untouched.

headline.main: Gatekeepers or Censors? How Tech Manages Online Speech
headline.print_headline: Tech Draws Blurry Lines In Deciding What to Ban

docs.abstract: “Hate speech” is extraordinarily vague and subjective. Libel and slander are not.
docs.snippet: “Hate speech” is extraordinarily vague and subjective. Libel and slander are not.
docs.lead_paragraph: Let me start by making a few things abundantly clear. First, Alex Jones is a loathsome conspiracy theorist who generates loathsome content. Second, there is no First Amendment violation when a private company chooses to boot anyone off a private platform. Third, it seems reasonably clear that Mr. Jones’s content isn’t just morally repugnant, it’s also legally problematic. He makes wild, false claims that may well cross the line into libel and slander.

headline.main: A Better Way to Ban Alex Jones

docs.abstract: The financial model pioneered by Apple is envied and copied by other companies. But getting it wrong is a big risk.
docs.snippet: The financial model pioneered by Apple is envied and copied by other companies. But getting it wrong is a big risk.
docs.lead_paragraph: With Apple Inc. now exceeding $1 trillion in market capitalization, it’s tempting to understand this moment in terms of the dominance of all-too-large companies and technology in our lives.

headline.main: Why Apple Is the Future of Capitalism

docs.abstract: The scholars, writing in a recent defamation suit, argued that much of what Mr. Jones of Infowars has said online does not deserve First Amendment safeguards.
docs.snippet: The scholars, writing in a recent defamation suit, argued that much of what Mr. Jones of Infowars has said online does not deserve First Amendment safeguards.
docs.lead_paragraph: Not long after several of the country’s biggest tech firms — namely Apple, Facebook and Google — kicked the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones off their various online platforms, Mr. Jones’s allies complained that he had been deprived of his First Amendment rights to free speech.

headline.main: Free Speech Scholars to Alex Jones: You’re Not Protected
headline.print_headline: Free-Speech Experts Argue Against Infowars Founder
